utterances.sentences: So are you curious? Are you concerned? Does it make you wonder what country this is that that could have happened to George Papadopoulos?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I'm sure George has many positive qualities. This focus on him reminds me of the focus of many people on the caravan to the run up to the election. Everybody in the Trump world bought that this was a horrible thing and nobody else did, which is why the Congress flipped, okay. And just here, George -- let me tell you what Donald Trump said about your friend, George, which is that he's a proven liar. What Michael Caputo said, he is a coffee boy. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('tablet', 'lb21', 'tablet-tw-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Hold on. I want to know --

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: No, this notion of spying --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, but I want to know what you think. Hold on. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb13', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb13', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I'll tell you exactly what I think.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Right -- to listen to Corey Lewandowski who was the campaign chairman?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But hold on, is okay with you that the Obama administration would dispatch spies to spy on an American citizen? It is clearly what happened.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I think what's all right is that when five friendly countries report to our Intelligence Agencies, that there are these reports that they are getting that are, you know, they credit that the Russians are in fact, as we now know from our Intelligence Community, trying to infiltrate the campaign and try to tip the scales, yes that troubles me. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But Papadopoulos -- so does it bother you that he wasn't a Russian spy? He got spied on by Obama, and then they sent him to -- no, he did.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: That's like saying babies in cages were done by Trump.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's what people say. Look, the President is in charge of the Executive Branch of government. The Trump campaign was spied on by the Obama administration. This guy went to jail but he didn't do anything. He didn't spy for the Russians.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: He lied. He admitted lying. That's why he went to jail.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: In the course of an investigation into something he didn't do.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Well, then he should have not --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So is that justice? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Well, he should have then not admitted lying and gone to trial if he thought he had the merits on his side?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But do you have a problem with that?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I don't have a problem. Look, we now know Donald Trump invited the Russians to help and they did and it benefited him. I'm troubled by the fact that nobody in the administration is as upset about that as they are about poor Carter Page and George Papadopoulos.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, their lives are destroyed and they didn't do anything wrong.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: That's what troubles me. And our country was attacked, according to Dick Cheney.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, it wasn't.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: As an active -- well, you take that up with him next time you talk with him. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That is so stupid. Our country was not -- you know, I don't care how many Republicans repeat that line. We're not even certain exactly where that information came from. How -- no, I'm serious. People who have looked at it carefully, people with deep knowledge of this question are not convinced that we've never seen evidence exactly how those servers were hacked. Why is that, I wonder?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I think I've seen people in this network interview Mike Pompeo, when he was head of CIA.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't care.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: He was unqualified about saying what the Russians did.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, I'm sure he wasn't -- that means -- let me just say how much that means to me. Oh, nothing. I want to see the evidence.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't trust anymore -- I don't trust my government just because they tell me to shut up and accept it. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I get it. And I'm not saying we should shut up and accept everything.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Ys, they were saying that.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: But every Intelligence Agency that's looked into it is unqualified about saying what the Russians did.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: They lie to us all the time and we're not allowed to ask questions over Russian agents?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I don't think we're confident enough to kind of all line in sync. I think the evidence was pretty clear.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, actually, they have lied -- all in sync. They lied about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. They're lying now on many levels.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And we have a right as American citizens to ask real questions and I'm going to. I don't care.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: We've had Republicans control Congress at the time and they could looked into it and why didn't they?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't care. I don't care in there. I don't care if they're Republicans. I don't trust them either.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Okay, that's the truth. Richard, thank you.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: More parents could soon face criminal charges in the Varsity Blues cheating scandal that is next. Plus another media outlet is being sued for its handling of the Covington High School news story. Fake story. That's also ahead. Stay tuned. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Nick Sandmann of Covington High School in Kentucky is suing NBC for $275 million for its coverage of his confrontation with Nathan Phillips, the supposed tribal leader and Vietnam veteran at the Lincoln Memorial. The lawsuit says correctly that NBC helped promote the fake storyline that Sandmann tried to intimidate Phillips. Later footage revealed exactly the opposite. As usual, Phillips came up and confronted Sadmann who was simply standing there. Even after it was clear exactly what happened because there were multiple tapes and they all showed the same thing, Sandmann went on "The Today Show" and the host badgered him like he was the aggressor. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Do you feel from this experience that you owe anybody an apology? Do you see your own fault? We looked at that video and thought about how it felt from the other's perspective. In other words, there were a lot of you, a handful of the others. There's something aggressive about standing there, standing your ground.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Something aggressive about standing there. Mollie Hemingway said that for years. She's a senior editor at "The Federalist" and she joins us tonight. Something kind of aggressive about you sitting there Mollie, I have to say. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MOLLIE HEMINGWAY, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Apparently. Yes, no it is --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I feel intimidated. So does this -- this lawsuit, I mean, I guess the upside is it really kind of offers a very clear explanation of a fraudulent story.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.sentences: Right. And it's not the first of these lawsuits that's been filed. There have been two others against two other media outlets. And what's important about it where it is interesting why people are paying attention, because currently, there aren't any repercussions really for getting stories completely wrong. And you're seeing this where the media feels sort of empowered to smear people, including, in this case, a child who had come out to Washington, DC for the March for Life, and they did this over the course of days. They said false things about this boy and his school that were demonstrably untrue. And right now, there's not a lot of accountability for this. You know, they do these false stories, they get ratings, they get money, and they never really are held accountable for it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And no one pauses to kind of reverse engineer it. How did this happen? How did this -- it began on a weekend. It's not really a news story, is it? I mean, there's a lot going on in the world, but the networks are all over this, like it was the most important thing.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.sentences: I think, because if you were to look into how this happened, it would not make the media look very good. They liked this story because it was a way to make the March for Life, an event that they do not cover year after year, despite the fact that hundreds of thousands of people attended each year in Washington, DC. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.sentences: It was a way to make the March for Life look bad. It was a way to make Donald Trump voters or supporters look bad. And so it was just convenient. It fit a narrative that they would like to perpetuate. And if they were to look at their own biases, and look at how those biases can lead to really bad news, they might start to think about other issues that they have covered poorly. I mean, you just -- in the earlier part of the show, we're talking about this Russia collusion hoax that went on for years and caused real damage to the country, including in our foreign policy, administration of government, and you're not even having people take accountability for that. Or the other people that have been smeared like Brett Kavanaugh, who, when he was going through his confirmation battle, so they don't want to look into it because I think the entire edifice would come crumbling down.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's all the destroyed lives. I mean, and no one ever stops to say well, we just wrecked someone's life. He will never work again. And we're responsible for that.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.sentences: And that's why I think this story has resonated so much with Nicholas Sandmann. They've done it to people who are adults. They've done it to people who they think deserve it. You know, Donald Trump, you can do whatever you want to him or conservatives or Republicans. This was a boy, you know, a teenage boy who was doing something good and got smeared as doing something bad. People sense the injustice of that and they want to see some people finally take responsibility for it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And I hope someone finally does. Mollie, thanks. It was great to see you.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.sentences: Great seeing you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Another of President Trump's Federal Reserve nominees has withdrawn his name after his character was assassinated. He joins us to respond, just a head. Plus Antifa got violent in Portland, Oregon yesterday. Cops did nothing. The journalist who was there joins us, after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, a group of fascists who claim to oppose fascism -- not very incredibly -- assembled yesterday in Portland for a May Day rally, they call themselves Antifa and as usual, things got violent when they gathered. Quillette editor and independent journalist, Andy Ngo was there. He wound up punched in the stomach and sprayed with bear mace. Portland Police did not intervene. Afterward, they described the event as entirely peaceful. Here's the tape.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, entirely peaceful. Andy Ngo joins us tonight. Andy, thanks a lot for coming on. So, just describe if you would, what we may have missed in that video. Why were you sprayed?

utterances.speaker: ANDY NGO, EDITOR, QUILLETTE
utterances.sentences: So yesterday's event was supposed to be a celebration of diversities and workers' rights, but in reality it was a celebration of Marxism, communism and political violence. Antifa had mobilized outside the I.C.E. office in an unlawful protest where they shut down streets in a critical area near a hospital. And it was there that they targeted my camera equipment. And then I was punched in the abdomen, both times were by different masked individuals. I immediately alerted the Portland Police officer who was standing yards away, and he let me know that if they stepped in to intervene that that would be an escalation and that that could incite the crowd. So he was going to do -- that he couldn't do anything. And if I wanted to, I could file a police report later. Later on the day, there was a brawl/riot outside the Cider Riot bar in in Portland. And it was there that I was singled out and targeted by a masked individual who sprayed me nearly point blank in the face with bare mace and blinded me. Fortunately, a woman who I have no idea who she is, but she led me across the street because I was -- I could not see and I was only there as a journalist and I was harassed and attacked all day. And when the riots happened, the police were nowhere in sight.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's disgusting. It's disgusting. Is this the official policy of the Portland Police not to protect the citizens of Portland from violence?

utterances.speaker: NGO
utterances.sentences: Of course they wouldn't say it like that. The policies that were explained to me was that in the middle of protests that are politically heated, if they step into intervene that could lead to an escalation and that's what they want to avoid.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I wonder if they take that same position on armed robbery and rape. I mean, it's demented. I will say, the one kind of upside of the whole event is some of the fascist wrote white privilege in chalk -- oh there, we have tape of it right there and misspelled privilege, which does kind of tell you everything about them. Really quickly, Andy, first, glad you're okay. Any idea why they targeted you?

utterances.speaker: NGO
utterances.sentences: Because one of my beats is I write about the accesses of the radical left in Portland, and Portland is the epicenter of radicalism on the left. My other beat is I write about hate crime hoaxes, and I go after the grifters, and they're angry about that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, they hate the truth. You're a brave man. Thank you for doing that.

utterances.speaker: NGO
utterances.sentences: Thank you for having me on.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: For covering it and for telling us about it. Appreciate it. Well, for the second time, in just two weeks, one of the President's nominees to the Federal Reserve Board has withdrawn after his character was attacked. They said almost nothing about his views and economics, but for the moment he was nominated, Heritage Foundation senior fellow Stephen Moore was tarred as a woman hater, a nut-job, a racist --unbelievable. Every vulnerability was hyped to hysterical proportions, and all it shades, the Brett Kavanaugh hearings just several months ago.

utterances.speaker: BRETT KAVANAUGH, ASSOCIATE JUSTICE OF THE SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: I love teaching law. But thanks to what some of you on this side of the committee have unleashed, I may never be able to teach again. My family and my name been totally and permanently destroyed by vicious and false additional accusations. The Swetnick thing is a joke. That is a farce. Ten days passed where all this nonsense is coming out and these things are printed and run breathlessly by cable news. You know, I wanted a hearing the next day. My family has been destroyed by this, Senator, destroyed.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, and he's not the only one. A lot of people have been destroyed by the left in the last couple of years. I made it through. Steve Moore hasn't been so lucky and we're happy to have him on this show anyway, or maybe especially now. Stephen Moore is the author of the book, "Trumponomics," and he joins us on set. So Stephen Moore, I mean, you can defend yourself, but let me just say what I was struck by watching your character get impugned is that nobody even mentioned your views on relevant issues, at all. It was, "You're a bad person" because you told a joke that must not have been a joke. You must be a bigot. I was fascinated see that CNN, where you worked up until about 20 minutes ago, leading the charge against you. How does that work?

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN MOORE, SENIOR FELLOW, HERITAGE FOUNDATION
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, let me just say that, you know, I'm bummed out today because I hate quitting. I'm not a quitter. And so I'm sad about that. And people, by the way, all over -- I'd be in airports, I'd be at, you know, at restaurants and people would come up to me. I mean, people were so great to me about you know, "Don't let these jackals get you."

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: They are jackals.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: And what surprised me, Tucker, and look, I'm not playing the victim here because the truth is, I have settled -- I have a two-mile long paper trail. I've given out 500 speeches and written a lot of articles, and I've said things that are in politic, things that --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Did you tell a joke -- did you make a mistake of telling a joke?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Almost always --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, damn you for telling a joke.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Almost all of the things that were a joke.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Look, again, I'm not saying that everything I've said, you know, some of the things I've said are stupid. And there should -- I wish there were a statute of limitation on stupidity. Because some of these things were 20 to 25 years old.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Who cares?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: But here's the point. I had hoped, you know -- I was excited about this. Because when Trump asked me to do this, I'm like, "This is great. I will have this ability to really talk about the economy and the amazing things that we can do if I'm at the Fed," and it never even came up. I mean, the left understood from the first couple of days, because they did surveys of the senators, the Republican senators love, you know, my economic views and so on. And that's when they launched this character assassination.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But I don't understand --

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: By the way, let me just say one thing.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: They went into my -- the most amazing thing. "The "Washington Post," "New York Times," CNN, they got my divorce settlement from 10 years ago, unsealed, so they could just put all of this dirt on me that had nothing to do with my qualifications to be on the Fed. As I've said a hundred times, I'll debate anybody on the economy and what we should do and what the best monetary policy is. It almost never came up.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The White House never should have given in to this. They should have not. They should have not have. They shouldn't have because that's more weakness, it draws more aggression.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: No, I've got to tell you one thing about this. Well, there's a lot of truth to that because -- but I will say that, you know, who know who the biggest -- the guy who did not want me to withdraw from this?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Who?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Donald J. Trump.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good. Well, I believe that.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: That's what I love about him. He is a fighter and I just said at the end -- I just had to say, "I don't know if I can."

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I believe it. So really quick, I thought you just resigned at CNN. They wanted you to work there and then I'm watching tonight, and they're telling me that like you're evil. How did that --

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Well, this is a little awkward for CNN because every night they trash me now, when for the last two and a half years, I had been their senior economics writer, and the things that they're talking about now are things that happened 20 years ago. Wait a minute, if I'm such a scoundrel and sexist, why did they have me on every night?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What's the answer?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, I don't know. You'd have to ask them. But the point is, you know, I don't think you should hold accountable, you know, for things that were written 25 years ago. They even been looked at my Christmas letters that we would send out to friends and family that were just kind of jokes where we'd make fun of everyone.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You've got to stand up to these people. I mean, this is -- it's disgusting what's happening. It's disgusting what happened to you and Kavanaugh and a lot of other people in this city. Anyway, Stephen Moore, you're always welcome on the show. Thank you for coming on.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you. Hillary Clinton's world grievance tour is going strong into its third year. Massive discount on the tickets, but whatever. Now she says America is lurching toward tyranny because she is not the President. New polls show voters disagree. That's just the head. But first, it's time for "Final Exam." Can you beat our experts at remembering the weird things that happened over the past seven days? A great lineup tonight after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Time now for "Final Exam" where the news professionals compete with one another to see who has been paying closest attention to what happened over the past seven days. Smart people this week, two new contestants joining us tonight. Fox News correspondent, Gillian Turner and University of Maryland Professor, Jason Nichols. Wow. Now, as I said to you both a second ago, smart people can be at a disadvantage on this show. So don't take it personally no matter what happens. Okay? Now, I'm going to repeat the rules. I know you know what they are. You look nervous.

utterances.speaker: GILLIAN TURNER, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: No, I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Okay, good.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I just want to go.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Okay, good. Hands on buzzers, I ask the question. First one to buzz in answers the question. You have to wait until I finish asking the question before you buzz in. That's key. You can answer once I acknowledge you by saying your name. Every correct answer is worth a single point. Each incorrect answer detracts a point from your total in the cruel math of "Final Exam." All right, best of five wins. Are you ready?

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: Born ready.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Born ready. Wow.

utterances.speaker: JASON NICHOLS, PROFESSOR, UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Question one.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I'm scared now.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Norwegian fishermen believe they have discovered an actual Russian spy in their waters. This time, it's an animal though with a recording device attached to its body. What kind of animal is it? Gillian.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: A whale.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: A whale. A whale? A whale can't be a spy.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I'm telling you it's a whale.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Is it some kind of whale?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Fishermen discovering a beluga whale wearing a Russian made harness. On it were written the words, "Equipment: St. Petersburg" fueling all kinds of speculation about spying. One newspaper reporting that the Russian military believe to have trained over sea mammals.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I don't stand a chance. This is over.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So you're saying that the whales are now spying for the Russians.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, did you say you wanted to concede now?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No don't. She is trying to intimidate you.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, I thought you said that.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: You know --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We'll see.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: We'll see how it goes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Okay, question two is multiple choice and these are the shoals upon which many a ship has gone down, okay -- these multiple choice questions. Okay, you've heard about the war on straws. There's now a war on Styrofoam single use Styrofoam, which state out of 50 just made history by banning Styrofoam by 2021? Is it A. State of Maine? B. State of New Hampshire? Or C. Vermont? Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to guess.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Professor Nichols.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to go with C. Vermont.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It sounds like a Vermont thing to do. Well, it does, it does.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: It does.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Is it actually a Vermont thing to do?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: "USA Today" reports Maine has become the first state to ban food containers made of Styrofoam. All goes into effect in 2021. Businesses will be prohibited from selling or distributing disposable food service containers made of Styrofoam. Violators will face fines of up to $100.00. The Democratic Governor who approved the ban says Styrofoam cannot be recycled and it eventually breaks down into micro plastics.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I should have known it was Maine. Damn you, Bernie Sanders.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Hard to believe. They've got a new Governor in the State of Maine and -- it is not Vermont -- all of a sudden. All right, question three. The New "Avengers" movie shattered box office records, $1.2 billion and its opening weekend, which 2020 candidate says Disney ought to do the ethical thing and give all profit from the film directly to employees. Which candidate running for President says that the studio ought to give the profit from the film to employees -- who would say that in the Democratic field? Like, I guess it could be anybody?

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: Elizabeth Warren?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't know, you've got to hit the buzzer and let me know.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I'm not. That's not a formal guess.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: You can do that? You can make a guess and not buzz?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No. You can't. You've got to buzz. You've got to buzz. Okay, I'll give you a hint. Man not a woman. Okay, this is really simple, which candidate is proposing socialism at the movies. Professor?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Bernie Sanders.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, Bernie Sanders. All right, is it Bernie Sanders?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I want to talk about Bernie Sanders, and something the Senator has tweeted out, he says what would be truly heroic, is if Disney use its profits from "Avengers" to pay all of its workers a middle class wage, instead of paying its CEO Bob Iger, $65.6 million over 1,400 times as much as the average worker at Disney makes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Can you say for the record? I agree with every word of that.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I kind of do, too.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You know, why is that so crazy? Disney's Bob Iger --

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: That was crazy.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, ridiculous. Good job. Question four, another multiple choice question. Robert Francis O'Rourke, known to some of us as Beto announced this week that his family is undergoing some kind of crisis. A pet turtle has run away from home. What is the name of Beto's runaway turtle? Is it A. Greg? B. Gus? C. Godfrey?

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I feel like you made the quiz harder this week.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No. Okay. It's one -- it's one of them. It's one of those three, it begins with a G. It's either a four letter word, a three letter word, or a seven letter word.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I would guess, but I have zero so --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Okay, you want to go for it?

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: Why don't you give us a clue.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Okay, I'll give you a clue. It starts with G. By the way, it's the kind of thing you would name a pet. I'm going to count down from four -- one. Jason Nichols.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to go with B. Gus.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Is it B. Gus?

utterances.speaker: BETO O'ROURKE, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: And to address some crises that we've got in our house, our baby turtle, Gus went missing here last night. And it does not look good. We followed the trail of turtle food out the living room, through the kitchen, the dog door into the backyard.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I love how you made his name French, too.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Beto. I try to do that. Don Lemon, Beto -- so what we have now is a sudden death situation. One to one.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: Aren't we two to one?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You were two to one. But now -- but the remarkable comeback from the Professor from Maryland.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: Right, right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You weren't even looking and Gus kind of sealed it. Okay, this is the final question. Are you ready?

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I'm ready?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Which member of congress brought shame to himself and his state today by marching around the capital with a toy chicken his way of mocking the Attorney General? Which congressman brought a toy chicken to work today?

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I can see him in my mind's eye.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You can see him.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Okay, I'll give you a hint. He represents the state of Tennessee. He represents the western part of Tennessee. He represents the city of Memphis.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I'm not a Capitol Hill correspondent. I don't know why you're looking at me.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Some people think he's related to Michael Cohen, but he's not because he is the same last name.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: That would be Cohen.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right, it would be Cohen, but what --

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Congressman Cohen.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: Representative Cohen.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're right, if his name is Cohen, it's definitely -- it would be Cohen, that is -- you're on it. You're on it there. Does he have a first name?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Who knows their first name?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We're going to go to the tape. Watch the tape.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Chicken Barr should have shown up today to answer questions. Attorney General who is picked for his legal acumen and his abilities would not be fearful of any other attorneys questioning him for 30 minutes.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Beto, acumen.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I think our judges are saying we have no choice but to give it to you.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: No. No, I object.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Oh, what a comeback.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't know what to say.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's the -- that's the weirdest segment we have ever done. All right. But --

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I object.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Look, I'm a marionette carrying out the orders of New York in all things, especially in this segment. All right, you get the coveted Eric Wemple coffee mug. Will you pass that to the Professor. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.sentences: I've got to go.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All right, that's it for this week's "Final Exam." Bizarre though it was. Pay attention to the news each week. Tune in on Thursdays to see if you can beat our experts. We will be right back.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, for years, the entire city of Washington accused the President of treason because at one point he said he wanted better relations with Russia. "Does he know that Russia is our number one enemy?" They squawk. But that's absurd. They're wrong. Russia isn't our top enemy, not even close. And it might be worth improving relations with them. Why wouldn't we? We have a top enemy, a real threat and it's China. They have far more people, a much larger economy, a much bigger military, far more spies and hackers. They are breaking into more servers in this country than Russia ever thought of and they're getting stronger every single year. Which brings us to Joe Biden. He is the front runner on the Democratic side. His position is, "don't worry." At a recent rally, Biden said this of China quote, "They're not bad guys. They're not competition for us." Biden has been pro-China for a long time. In 2011, he wrote an op-ed arguing that China getting stronger is not a threat to the United States. Kind of interesting. Why would he say something like that so demonstrably untrue? Maybe he's a Chinese spy. No, we're not going to make that allegation, we're just going to make the point that he's dead wrong. Because he is. Well, Hillary Clinton is not running for President, not once again, but she is still in the news. She was on MSNBC last night and she says she is mad, because she is not in the White House, and therefore, this country is lurching toward tyranny.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER FIRST LADY
utterances.sentences: If they find, barring contempt, which they have no reason to, because he actually is -- He is the President's defense lawyer. He is not the Attorney General of the United States.

utterances.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, MSNBC ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Barr's argument about that today he went, I believe, even further than he went in his 19-page memo. Not just the President can obstruct justice, that is the President can't be investigated if the President doesn't want to be investigated.

utterances.speaker: CLINTON
utterances.sentences: And that is the road to tyranny. That is what authoritarians believes and those who service them argue. If the President were not in office, he would have been indicted for obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: There was a lot of agreement during that segment last night, as you can imagine, didn't do that well in the ratings. It turns out not all people want to watch that. I wonder why? Probably because there was so much projection as there always is going on. At one point Hillary said that President Trump is obsessed with her. "He is not living in my head," she insisted, "I'm living in his." She is not living in most people's heads in this country. A new poll from Rasmussen finds that only 42 percent of Americans think the country would have been better off had Hillary won, 48 percent disagree. Author and columnist, Mark Steyn is on the fence on that question. He joins us tonight to deliver his verdict -- Mark Steyn.

utterances.speaker: MARK STEYN, AUTHOR AND COLUMNIST
utterances.sentences: Well, I was on the fence, Tucker. She lost because she was a stinking candidate. But look, it isn't funny anymore. I mean, basically, this is the woman who is more responsible than anyone for the totally pointless and discreditable Russian investigation that destroyed your first guest's life -- Papadopoulos. We had all this talk in November 2016, about how, oh, you know, America is the only country that has the peaceful transfer of power, which I always find a little odd because I can't remember the last time I saw a Belgian or Danish Prime Minister hanging from a lamppost. But the fact is that the more people who said it, the more it became conditional because it was her refusal to lose gracefully, that in fact enabled this last disgusting two years in which the losing party's men on the inside have conducted an investigation into the duly elected president. It's quite disgraceful. She is quite disgraceful. And to listen to your friend, Richard Goodstein. I like Richard, but for him laughing at what happened to -- Papadopoulos landed at Washington and the FBI agents seized him and put him in shackles -- shackles -- for doing nothing. And that's all on Hillary because she didn't know how to lose, because Clinton's shouldn't lose.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And she's lecturing us about tyranny. Amazing.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: No, yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, the self-awareness is in short supply, I would say in Washington. Mark Steyn.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. And it could happen to Richard and all the other defenders of Hillary Clinton, too.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's true. I hope it doesn't. Mark Steyn, great to see you tonight. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Thanks a lot, Tucker. Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We're out of time. Don't know what happened to the hour, but we will be back, we can promise you tomorrow night 8:00 pm. The show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness, and especially groupthink from which we dissent until they shut us up. They haven't yet. We have good news for you. It's not over. 9 p.m., Sean Hannity awaits in New York City. Take it away, Sean Hannity. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
